thread.title: Tiger moves up to 11th at state
thread.title_full: Tiger moves up to 11th at state

title: Tiger moves up to 11th at state
text:
Tiger moves up to 11th at state Palladium-Item 8:34 p.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Mark Shafer, left, has coached his daughter Shelly Shafer during her senior year, and the two will travel to the state finals Friday and Saturday. (Photo: Jesus Jimenez/Palladium-Item) 108 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CARMEL, Ind. -- Mark Shafer has watched the work his daughter, Shelly, has put in to become one of the state's top golfers. 
On Saturday, he watched her work her way up the state leaderboard. 
Shelly Shafer fired a 75 at Prairie View Golf Club, 10 strokes better than the Hagerstown senior's Friday score, and the fourth-lowest output during the second round of the state finals. 
Shafer finished with a two-day total of 160, good for a tie for 11th place, and the top placing for a Hagerstown golfer at the state meet. 
“Today I kind of just came out and had a little more fun with it," Shelly Shafer said. "I knew the course better than yesterday." 
Shafer shot an 85 on Friday and was tied for 31st place. She played consistent in Saturday's gloomy weather conditions and birdied No. 17 on the way to a 3-over par day. 
"After yesterday, the start she had, how she kind of stuck with it ... she got a decent score and came today and played lights out today," said Mark Shafer, also Hagerstown's coach. 
"When she got in trouble, she got out of it. She saved par and played probably five holes in the rain." 
Alexis Miestowski of Lake Central won the tournament with 145 while Evansville North's Hadley Walts and Bloomington South's Cherise Otter tied for second with 151. 
Evansville North won the team title with 651. Westfield was second with 677. 
Shafer also earned all-state honors from the coaches association. 
"I'm just really proud of my daughter," Mark Shafer said. 
"I was so much in the moment just watching her play. I know I’m going to see her play more golf, but I guess the nice part is we get to start playing golf together more now." 
Sharing the state experience with her family was special. 
"I never thought I’d have that opportunity,” Shelly Shafer said.
